projectName: Monitoring Harrier Field and Erie Landfill at the NJ Meadowlands
descriptionShort: Determine the usefulness of contaminated reclaimed grassland and wetland sites in the New Jersey Meadowlands for migratory and breeding birds
descriptionLong:
Habitat degradation is a persistent problem for birds worldwide, especially for species reliant on native grassland and wetland ecosystems. Many restoration efforts have been made to improve degraded sites for breeding and migrating birds but contamination often persists. There is a question as to whether birds successfully utilize these partially-restored, contaminated areas. This project’s goals are to (1) determine the usefulness of historically contaminated reclaimed grassland and wetland sites in the New Jersey Meadowlands as breeding and migratory stopover habitats for native wild birds and (2) track migratory success for select species utilizing these sites with Motus technology.
Contaminated landscapes like The Meadowlands are frequently assumed to be of poor ecological quality and thus harmful or unusable to wildlife. These areas are often slated for development as a way to utilize otherwise “useless” land. However, pilot data from 2019-20 indicate that several restored areas in the Meadowlands provide useful breeding and migratory stopover habitat to many native grassland and wetland bird species including several of conservation concern. This project seeks to quantify avian biodiversity at these sites, the breeding success of birds utilizing these areas, and their stopover success during fall migration. Motus wildlife tracking technology will also be used to determine success of these birds completing their fall migrations.
In this project, two sites in the New Jersey Meadowlands, Harrier Meadow and the adjacent Erie Landfill in North Arlington, New Jersey, will be assessed to determine habitat use and breeding success of native birds in the summer months and the usefulness of these sites as stopovers to refuel during fall migration and ultimately, to complete their migratory journeys. Harrier Meadow consists of grassland patches bordered by reclaimed saltmarsh scrubland; Erie, a capped landfill, is a mid-successional restored grassland. Both are contaminated with heavy metals, predominantly mercury, and Erie is significantly more contaminated. Despite the presumed poor quality of these sites, it is hypothesized that avian biodiversity will be high and that birds utilizing these areas for breeding, including species of conservation concern, will be ultimately successful. It is also hypothesized that birds stopping over in these areas during the fall will sufficiently accumulate required fat reserves to successfully complete their migratory journeys.
If the hypotheses are supported, the project would provide evidence that these and other restored sites are important to native bird populations despite their degraded status, and that they should remain accessible to birds. These data could be used to better inform management decisions for degraded areas, such as preventing their development or investing in restoration efforts.
Nanotags will be utilized in this study, allowing birds to be tracked by the North American Motus network over their entire migratory journeys. Nanotags will help to determine successful completion of fall migration by individuals and may provide valuable, novel insight on migratory routes or highlight areas of loss that could inform regional conservation efforts. Lotek radio-tracking nanotags will be affixed to individuals of species of conservation concern frequently encountered at these sites: Savannah Sparrows (Passerculus sandwichensis) and three species of Wood Warblers (Parulidae). Affixed nanotags in conjunction with the Motus tower and omnidirectional receiver will allow close monitoring of the land use patterns of the tagged birds including locations utilized during stopovers and length of stopovers in the two study sites and other Meadowlands locations. Tagged birds will then be tracked by the full North American Motus network to determine if they successfully complete fall migration.
The study is likely to provide novel insights into the migratory ecology of these species as recent increases in coverage of the Motus network and improved battery technologies have allowed.

projectName: The Effects of Window Strikes on Migratory Routes and Successful Completion of Migration in Passerines
descriptionShort: Comparing window struck but ostensibly recovered migrating birds' migration to that of control birds
descriptionLong:
Worldwide, window strikes by birds are estimated to kill in excess of a billion birds per year, making windows one of the worst culprits in direct avian mortality and loss. The threat of window strikes is especially high during annual migrations, when birds briefly enter many novel environments, and during breeding season, when many young and inexperienced birds are learning to fly. Mitigation of avian window strikes has become a widely researched area in wildlife conservation with much of this research taking place in urban centers involving skyscrapers and significant light pollution attracting birds to the site including Newark, New Jersey, not far from the NJ Meadowlands. Though dead birds rightfully get the majority of the attention, many additional birds collide with buildings but ostensibly recover and fly away; these birds are not considered in current mortality estimates. However, pilot data suggest these birds may suffer negative long-term effects of traumatic brain injury, including an inability to correctly orient or navigate and therefore, the presumed inability to complete necessary annual migrations.
Currently, many rehabilitation facilities accept birds that have struck windows and provide supportive care such as tube feeding, fracture stabilizations, and safety until the bird is self-sufficient and able to fly effectively once again. However, the concern remains that perhaps birds are not able to be truly rehabilitated as they may have sustained damage to critical areas of the brain or retina responsible for orientation and navigation. We propose affixing nanotags to
species of concern that strike windows but survive for further insight into whether or not rehabilitating window-struck birds is a viable option.
We propose to affix nanotags to window struck but recovered birds deemed healthy and ready for release by a licensed avian rehabilitator as well as control birds caught during normal banding operations at the Meadowlands Banding Station. Birds will be matched in species, date, and overall condition, and all will be released as a cohort at the Meadowlands. We hypothesize window struck birds will not complete migrations successfully when compared to “normal” birds; if supported, this suggests that estimates of avian mortality due to window strikes may be seriously under-estimated and should incorporate window struck birds who do not die on impact. We further hypothesize that stunned birds, or those that are releasable same-day after a short recovery period, will complete migration more frequently than birds who sustain more serious injuries resulting in prolonged recovery periods, or that the latter will show aberrant migratory patterns.
This study incorporates four years of pilot data from two sources studying window strikes in birds; we have reliable access to window-struck, recovered birds and permissions to affix tags to them. Species involved in this study include Palm Warbler (Setophaga palmarum), Northern Waterthrush (Parkesia noveboracensis), Song Sparrow (Melospiza melodia), and Gray Catbird (Dumetella carolinensis) due to reliable encounters of both species throughout migration at both window-strike sites, including local Newark, NJ, and at the Meadowlands Banding Station.

projectName: Potential Negative Effects of Captive Raising on Migration in Passerines
descriptionShort: Tracking the migration of captive-raised birds raised in a rehabilitation setting versus control birds
descriptionLong:
Each year, tens of thousands of orphaned and injured baby birds are brought to wild bird rehabilitators in New Jersey alone to be raised in captivity by humans, then released once they demonstrate that they can find food and, presumably, fend for themselves. However, very little research has been done on the success of these captive-raised passerine birds in the wild, mostly because rehabilitators are generally not also research scientists. Previous research has shown that it is necessary for nestlings of some bird species to imprint on the night sky to be able to effectively navigate and/or to imprint on photoperiod to appropriately time their migrations; neither the night sky nor photoperiod cues are available to young birds raised indoors by rehabilitators, presenting a potentially devastating problem. Additionally, birds raised in captivity are generally fed an unnatural diet and may experience physiological changes during development that make it difficult to transition to a wild diet, which may also lead to high mortality.
We hypothesize that passerines raised in captivity will demonstrate abnormalities in migratory timing and routes when compared to birds raised naturally by their parents, and will experience higher mortality. We propose to affix nanotags to fledgling birds raised in a rehabilitation setting and pair them with birds of the same species and age on the same dates captured and banded at the Meadowlands Banding Station to track their migratory timing, route,
and success. We are also interested in their survival rates, and we hypothesize that it will be much lower than wild-raised conspecifics, as demonstrated in some species such as Mallards. Species of concern for this project include American Robin (Turdus migratorius), Blue Jay (Cyanositta cristata), and Common Grackle (Quiscalus quiscula) due to likelihood of encounter at Meadowlands Banding Station and high numbers of these species admitted to rehabilitation centers in New Jersey each year. Robins and grackles are migratory, and Blue Jays, though non-migratory, will add data to the mortality portion of the study.

Tracking movement of Northern Saw-whet Owls in Coastal BC
descriptionShort: Pilot project to assess movement behaviour of Northern Saw-whet Owls in coastal areas of British Columbia using MOTUS
descriptionLong:
The Northern Saw-whet Owl is a small nocturnal owl found in portions of southern Canada and northern USA. The species is partly migratory throughout its range, with large numbers of owls getting captured and banded at monitoring stations each fall, including hundreds captured at the Rocky Point Bird Observatory (RPBO) on the southern tip of Vancouver Island. These banding numbers suggest that significant numbers of owls migrate through southern Vancouver Island each fall, however the migratory routes and destination for these birds remain poorly understood because few birds are subsequently recaptured. The MOTUS Wildlife Tracking System, which consists of a large growing network of VHF receiving stations in Canada and around the World, provides an excellent opportunity to study migration and habitat use by Northern Saw-whet Owls. MOTUS
receivers automatically detect and record signals from radio transmitters (tags) deployed on birds that pass within their detection radius. This collaborative pilot project by Vancouver Island University (VIU), RPBO and the Tatlayoko Bird Observatory (TLBO) aims to use MOTUS to assess the movement behaviour of Northern Saw-whet Owls in coastal areas of BC. Up to 38 Northern Saw-whet Owls will be captured and tagged at three main locations during Fall 2021: Nanaimo (VIU), Metchosin (RPBO), and Tatlayoko Lake (TLBO). Owls will be captured with mist nets and banded as part of the owl monitoring programs operating at each project location. Individual owls selected for tagging will receive a Lotek Avian NanoTag attached on the birds' back using a leg-loop harness. The tag will emit a VHF radio signal every 29 seconds for up to 2 years. Once released with activated tags, owl movements will be determined by the MOTUS receiver network to help elucidate the species' migratory behaviour.

descriptionShort: Combine radio-tracking and gene expression profiles to predict the adaptive capacity of wild migratory birds.
descriptionLong:
1. Investigate landscape-scale movements, stopover duration and departure behaviour of selected species of birds. To this aim we will deploy encoded radio-transmitters on birds during both spring and autumn migration and analyze radio-tracking data.
2. Associate gene expression levels with the duration of migration stopovers and with different migration seasons including different life cycle stages. Genes associated with metabolism, physiology and behaviour will be examined.
3. Model the migratory birds' response to climate change scenarios.

descriptionShort: Migration behavior and physiological response of shorebirds in California to drought and habitat availability
descriptionLong: This study will quantify the overwintering movements of shorebirds (Dunlin, Long-billed Dowitchers, and Least Sandpipers) and subsequent migration behavior in response to habitat availability in the Central Valley of California relative to potential use of coastal wetland sites less impacted by drought and water management. In addition, this study will quantify physiological stress response of captured shorebirds to habitat availability and use of alternative habitat types (coastal vs managed wetlands and flooded agriculture in the Central Valley, CA). Movements will be tracked with the timing, stopover, annual return rates and rates between California, Mexico, British Columbia and elsewhere along Pacific Flyway where tagged birds are detected.

descriptionShort: Evaluating Henslow's Sparrow habitat use in North Carolina
descriptionLong: Henslow’s Sparrow populations have shown significant long-term declines throughout their range credited to severe habitat loss and degradation and fire suppression. In North Carolina, the species is considered of conservation priority by the North Carolina Wildlife Resources Commission and the US Fish and Wildlife Service. However, formulating conservation measures to enhance the persistence of Henslow’s Sparrows in North Carolina is constrained by lack of data to evaluate species resiliency, representativeness, and redundancy. Using radio telemetry, I will determine the Henslow's response to prescribed fire on their breeding grounds, calculate home range sizes and kernel density estimates, and determine the sparrow's habitat use of the breeding site. The findings of my research will help state and federal conservation agencies identify appropriate conservation and management measures to promote the persistence of the Henslow’s Sparrow in North Carolina.
